text.section:
A physician may delegate medical acts to a physician assistant only after:
A delegation agreement has been executed and filed with the Board; and
Any advanced duties have been authorized as required under subsection (c) of this section.

section.section:
The Board may not require prior approval of a delegation agreement that includes advanced duties, if an advanced duty will be performed in a hospital or ambulatory surgical facility, provided that:
A physician, with credentials that have been reviewed by the hospital or ambulatory surgical facility as a condition of employment, as an independent contractor, or as a member of the medical staff, supervises the physician assistant;
The physician assistant has credentials that have been reviewed by the hospital or ambulatory surgical facility as a condition of employment, as an independent contractor, or as a member of the medical staff; and
Each advanced duty to be delegated to the physician assistant is reviewed and approved within a process approved by the governing body of the health care facility before the physician assistant performs the advanced duties.

In any setting that does not meet the requirements of paragraph (1) of this subsection, a primary supervising physician shall obtain the Board's approval of a delegation agreement that includes advanced duties, before the physician assistant performs the advanced duties.

Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, a primary supervising physician shall obtain the Board's approval of a delegation agreement before the physician assistant may administer, monitor, or maintain general anesthesia or neuroaxial anesthesia, including spinal and epidural techniques, under the agreement.

text.section: For a delegation agreement containing advanced duties that require Board approval, the Committee shall review the delegation agreement and recommend to the Board that the delegation agreement be approved, rejected, or modified to ensure conformance with the requirements of this title.
The Committee may conduct a personal interview of the primary supervising physician and the physician assistant.

section.section:
On review of the Committee's recommendation regarding a primary supervising physician's request to delegate advanced duties as described in a delegation agreement, the Board:
May approve the delegation agreement; or
If the physician assistant does not meet the applicable education, training, and experience requirements to perform the specified delegated acts, may modify or disapprove the delegation agreement; and
If the Board takes an action under item 1 of this item:

To the extent practicable, the Board shall approve a delegation agreement or take other action authorized under this subsection within 90 days after receiving a completed delegation agreement including any information from the physician assistant and primary supervising physician necessary to approve or take action.

text.section: If the Board determines that a primary or alternate supervising physician or physician assistant is practicing in a manner inconsistent with the requirements of this title or Title 14 of this article, the Board on its own initiative or on the recommendation of the Committee may demand modification of the practice, withdraw the approval of the delegation agreement, or take other disciplinary action under § 14-404 or § 15-314 of this article.

A primary supervising physician may not delegate medical acts under a delegation agreement to more than four physician assistants at any one time, except in a hospital or in the following nonhospital settings:
A correctional facility;
A detention center; or
A public health facility.
A person may not coerce another person to enter into a delegation agreement under this subtitle.

A physician may supervise a physician assistant:
As a primary supervising physician in accordance with a delegation agreement approved by the Board under this subtitle; or
As an alternate supervising physician if:
The alternate supervising physician supervises in accordance with a delegation agreement filed with the Board;
The alternate supervising physician supervises no more than four physician assistants at any one time, except in a hospital, correctional facility, detention center, or public health facility;
The alternate supervising physician's period of supervision, in the absence of the primary supervising physician, does not exceed:
The period of time specified in the delegation agreement; and
A period of 45 consecutive days at any one time; and
The physician assistant performs only those medical acts that:
Have been delegated under the delegation agreement filed with the Board; and
Are within the scope of practice of the primary supervising physician and alternate supervising physician.

In the event of a sudden departure, incapacity, or death of a primary supervising physician, a designated alternate supervising physician may assume the role of the primary supervising physician by submitting a new delegation agreement to the Board within 15 days.
Individual members of the Board are not civilly liable for actions regarding the approval, modification, or disapproval of a delegation agreement described in this section.
A physician assistant may practice in accordance with a delegation agreement filed with the Board under this subtitle.
